children.subject: Don't need it for interviews given that you are practicing all sorts of problems from leetcode/hackerrank. You'll be fine.

And if you're one of those people who will never self study anything, then take the course. It will give you practice solving problems, which could help with interviews. Most of it is overkill though if not interested.

For anyone skeptical:

1. Look at the syllabus https://cs170.org/materials/

2. Look at Cracking Coding Interview and Leetcode and/or google what types of questions companies ask. You can then decide for yourself if it's worth taking. You have 1 problem set a week no coding if I recall, just pseudocode and some proofs, I think 4-7 problems. The problems are ranked in difficulty, but I recall most of them being hard. There's also 1 project that I didn't find extremely helpful in learning material or becoming a better programmer, but it's challenging and could be rewarding.

This has been asked so many times, I hope this response gives clarity:

1. 170 will teach you new types of Algorithms. BFS and DFS in 61B are algorithms, think of them as search algorithms. Think of all the sorts as sort algorithms. Now think of techniques like "divide and conquer". Well, what is divide and conquer? It's one of the topics you will learn in 170. But here is the thing...if you've taken 61B, you can self study divide and conquer, and see that it's just something you can master through practice problems. Where do you get these practice problems in 170? By doing the HW. If you didn't take 170, how would you learn this topic? You would read a chapter, look at a youtube video, read an article, and do practice problems on leetcode or something.

Now, this is a very basic example of what you learn in 170. There are really complicated topics. DP is probably the most relevant to interviews. The code is 61B level, and so is the idea. As a result, your data structure, algorithm, and programming maturity is sufficient to watch a video, read a book/article to learn DP. Then, you can practice on Leetcode. How is this practiced in 170? You guessed it, through HW.

This self studying can occur with all the topics. They are not trivial, but you don't need to spend a semester studying the material. The reason I wouldn't recommend 170 for someone who simply wants it for interview prep is because of this:

The HW is very difficult and time consuming. You want to interview prep, but you are spending hours not understanding how to solve 1 problem, 1 problem you don't have a solution for until you provide 1, and will be graded on for correctness. Then you will have to do a difficult project, and take 1-3 exams that will be quite difficult.

If you're interested in the material, take the course. But if not, you can spend all those hours taking the course doing Leetcode. This is a better use of your time.

history.content:
It's a common misconception that 170 is a direct continuation of 70. It's much more similar to 61B. Many students who don't like the math in 70 are relieved by the pre-MT2 material of 170. For the most part, 170 has done an excellent job of extracting the math out of algorithms.

I don't think 170 is mandatory. However, I do think it helps with interviews. There is certainly some material that may show up but is not covered in 61B. Even if you don't end up using the algorithms we teach you, you will be more comfortable in algorithm design by the end of it. Of course, Leetcode and Hackerrank can be used to learn 170 material. This is why I think it isn't mandatory. But the comfort of being able to sit back and have the material handed to you in a sensible order is a good enough reason to take the class.

The project is a hit or miss, but I think this semester's was more of a hit than usual (I may be biased). If you do take it in the fall, I can assure you the TAs in charge will try to make the project as useful as possible.

So I had planned on taking 170 during the Fall. However, I'm also taking 161, and 162, so I decided to switch to 186 since I know that 170 is going to be a really hard class for me since I really struggled in 70. My question is, if I spend a lot of time practicing on sites like leetcode and hackerrank, and watching 170 lectures over summer, can I gain that same knowledge without taking the class, or at least pushing it off until spring? And how important is 170 anyways? If someone could just clear that up for me, I would really appreciate it.
history.subject: How Important is 170

history.content: I'm a rising senior, so I'm going to be applying for jobs next year, and so I had planned on taking 170 during the Fall. However, I'm also taking 161, and 162, so I decided to switch to 186 since I know that 170 is going to be a really hard class for me since I really struggled in 70. My question is, if I spend a lot of time practicing on sites like leetcode and hackerrank, and watching 170 lectures over summer, can I gain that same knowledge without taking the class, or at least pushing it off until spring?
history.subject: How Important is 170
